elements.content: The reaction of bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid (H4L, generated in situ from its dianhydride) with alkali metal hydroxides in water under mild conditions gives the series of complexes [Li2(H2L)(H2O)2]·2H2O (2), [Li4(L)(H2O)3.5]·1.5H2O (3), [Na2(H2L)(H2O)3]·H2O (4), [K2(H2L)(H2O)2]·H2O (5), [Rb(H3L)(H2O)] (6), and [Cs(H3L)(H2O)] (7), while the complex [Ba2(L)(H2O)5]·0.5H2O (8) was obtained from BaCO3 under hydrothermal conditions. All these compounds are three-dimensional frameworks, except for 4 and 6, which are two-dimensional assemblies. Both 4 and 5 display tubular subunits based on doubly or triply bridged cation dimers. The cation coordination number varies from 4 for Li to 9 for Ba, while the number of metal ions bound to the ligand H4−x L x− ranges from 4 (Rb) to 11 (Li). No two complexes display the same bonding scheme, this being a result of the variety of carboxylic/ate groups coordination modes, either chelating, mono-, bi-, tri- or tetradentate. These are the first alkali metal ion complexes with a cyclohexane polycarboxylate derivative and very rare examples of the use of H4−x L x− as a ligand. The crystal structure of the dihydrate H4L·2H2O (1) is also described, which is a hydrogen bonded three-dimensional framework incorporating water tetramers.

elements.content: The complexes formed by the whole range of alkali metal ions as well as barium ions with a rigid cyclohexane tetracarboxylate derivative display a wide range of coordination modes, with chelating, mono-, bi-, tri-, or tetradentate carboxylic/ate groups, and compact two- or three-dimensional assemblies of different topologies are obtained.

elements.content: The s-block alkali and alkaline-earth metal ions are ubiquitous in coordination and materials chemistry, but their potential as building units in metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) is somewhat neglected by comparison with that of d-block metal ions, and only recently was it the subject of a systematic overview. The metal ions in each of the groups 1 and 2 constitute an ensemble of similar charge but differing radius and electronegativity, resulting in different coordination numbers which can be exploited to generate metal−organic polymers of variable, if hardly predictable, architecture. Lithium-containing MOFs are of particular interest due to their potential applications as lightweight materials for gas storage. We have recently used pyrazinetetracarboxylic acid, a ligand displaying a large array of 10 donor atoms, to synthesize two- and three-dimensional coordination polymers with alkali metal ions (Na+, K+, Cs+), which demonstrated the remarkable assembling power of this ligand, with as many as 12 coordinated cations in the case of Cs+. Among the polycarboxylic acids which could be suitable to get metal−organic assemblies, we recently turned our attention to the all-exo isomer of bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid (denoted H4L hereafter), which presents four carboxylic groups attached to a rigid, bicyclic core containing a cyclohexane ring subunit in the boat conformation (Scheme ). This molecule has seldom been used as a ligand, and the crystal structures of only two complexes are reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.31); the first is a Sr2+ complex with a three-dimensional architecture, and the second is a two-dimensional Cu2+ complex which also involves phenanthroline ligands. It is noteworthy that, apart from this Sr2+ complex, no alkali or alkaline-earth complex with cyclohexane polycarboxylate derivatives is reported in the CSD. We have recently shown that, when reacted with lanthanide ions under hydrothermal conditions, H4L (generated in situ from its dianhydride, denoted Lda) undergoes oxidation and isomerization to give all-trans 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid. We report herein the synthesis and crystal structure of the complexes formed by partially or completely deprotonated H4L with the series of alkali metal ions (Li+−Cs+) as well as Ba2+; the crystal structure of an uncoordinated dihydrate of H4L is also described.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The s-block alkali and alkaline-earth metal ions are ubiquitous in coordination and materials chemistry, but their potential as building units in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is somewhat neglected by comparison with that of d-block metal ions, and only recently was it the subject of a systematic overview. The metal ions in each of the groups 1 and 2 constitute an ensemble of similar charge but differing radius and electronegativity, resulting in different coordination numbers which can be exploited to generate metal-organic polymers of variable, if hardly predictable, architecture. Lithium-containing MOFs are of particular interest due to their potential applications as lightweight materials for gas storage. We have recently used pyrazinetetracarboxylic acid, a ligand displaying a large array of 10 donor atoms, to synthesize two- and three-dimensional coordination polymers with alkali metal ions (Na+, K+, Cs+), which demonstrated the remarkable assembling power of this ligand, with as many as 12 coordinated cations in the case of Cs+. Among the polycarboxylic acids which could be suitable to get metal-organic assemblies, we recently turned our attention to the all-exo isomer of bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid (denoted H4L hereafter), which presents four carboxylic groups attached to a rigid, bicyclic core containing a cyclohexane ring subunit in the boat conformation (Scheme ). This molecule has seldom been used as a ligand, and the crystal structures of only two complexes are reported in the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD, Version 5.31); the first is a Sr2+ complex with a three-dimensional architecture, and the second is a two-dimensional Cu2+ complex which also involves phenanthroline ligands. It is noteworthy that, apart from this Sr2+ complex, no alkali or alkaline-earth complex with cyclohexane polycarboxylate derivatives is reported in the CSD. We have recently shown that, when reacted with lanthanide ions under hydrothermal conditions, H4L (generated in situ from its dianhydride, denoted Lda) undergoes oxidation and isomerization to give all-trans 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylic acid. We report herein the synthesis and crystal structure of the complexes formed by partially or completely deprotonated H4L with the series of alkali metal ions (Li+-Cs+) as well as Ba2+; the crystal structure of an uncoordinated dihydrate of H4L is also described.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

Bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic dianhydride, RbOH, and CsOH⋅H2O were purchased from Aldrich, LiOH⋅H2O, NaOH, and KOH from Prolabo, and BaCO3 from Carlo Erba. Elemental analyses were performed by Service de Microanalyse du CNRS at Gif-sur-Yvette, France.

elements.content: An equimolar solution of Lda and uranyl nitrate in demineralized water was heated at 180 °C in a closed glass vessel for half an hour and then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature, yielding crystals of 1 within two weeks.
elements.clean_text:
H4L⋅2H2O (1)

An equimolar solution of Lda and uranyl nitrate in demineralized water was heated at 180 °C in a closed glass vessel for half an hour and then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature, yielding crystals of 1 within two weeks.

elements.content: Lda (50 mg, 0.20 mmol), LiOH·H2O (17 mg, 0.41 mmol), and demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure until complete dissolution (about 15 mn). The solution was then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature and colorless crystals of complex 2 appeared within two weeks (36 mg, 49% yield). Anal. Calcd. for C12H18Li2O12: C, 39.15; H, 4.93. Found: C, 39.06; H, 4.79%.

elements.content: The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting “Paratone-N” oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects for compounds 4−8 were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. In the absence of a suitable anomalous scatterer, the Friedel pairs have been merged for compound 3. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Atom O11 in compound 4, which pertains to a coordinated water molecule, was found to be disordered over two positions which were refined with occupancy parameters constrained to sum to unity and restraints on displacement parameters. The solvent water molecule in 8 (O14) was given an occupancy factor of 0.5 so as to retain an acceptable displacement parameter and to account for its closeness to its image by symmetry. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps in all compounds (except for those of water molecules O11 in 4 and O14 in 8), and all the others were introduced at calculated positions; all were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

The data were collected at 150(2) K on a Nonius Kappa-CCD area detector diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ 0.71073 Å). The crystals were introduced into glass capillaries with a protecting "Paratone-N" oil (Hampton Research) coating. The unit cell parameters were determined from 10 frames, then refined on all data. The data (combinations of φ- and ω-scans giving complete data sets up to θ = 25.7° and a minimum redundancy of 4 for 90% of the reflections) were processed with HKL2000. Absorption effects for compounds 4-8 were corrected empirically with the program SCALEPACK. The structures were solved by direct methods with SHELXS-97, expanded by subsequent Fourier-difference synthesis and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 with SHELXL-97. In the absence of a suitable anomalous scatterer, the Friedel pairs have been merged for compound 3. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Atom O11 in compound 4, which pertains to a coordinated water molecule, was found to be disordered over two positions which were refined with occupancy parameters constrained to sum to unity and restraints on displacement parameters. The solvent water molecule in 8 (O14) was given an occupancy factor of 0.5 so as to retain an acceptable displacement parameter and to account for its closeness to its image by symmetry. The hydrogen atoms bound to oxygen atoms were found on Fourier-difference maps in all compounds (except for those of water molecules O11 in 4 and O14 in 8), and all the others were introduced at calculated positions; all were treated as riding atoms with an isotropic displacement parameter equal to 1.2 times that of the parent atom.

H4L·2H2O (1) was obtained during an attempt at crystallizing the uranyl complex with deprotonated H4L (which could be done under slightly different conditions and will be reported elsewhere); a view of the structure is given in Figure . In the solid state, the H4L molecule is devoid of any symmetry element and it displays the expected geometry, with the all-cis configuration and all carboxylic groups in equatorial position. The four −COOH groups make dihedral angles of 59.04(18), 60.25(17), 61.0(2), and 43.4(3)° with the basal plane defined by the four atoms of the cyclohexane ring bearing the four carboxylic substituents (rms deviation 0.003 Å). Such tilting of proximal acid groups likely minimizes steric hindrance, as observed in all-trans 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylate, with all the carboxylate groups in equatorial positions. Two proximal carboxylic groups are involved in hydrogen bonds with their counterparts in two different molecules (Table ), which results in the formation of zigzag chains directed along the b axis. The other two carboxylic groups are hydrogen bonded to the two water molecules, these being in their turn hydrogen bond donors toward each other or their image by symmetry and toward two unprotonated oxygen atoms from two different H4L molecules. Centrosymmetric, tetrameric water clusters are formed, in which the hydrogen bonding is homodromic, that is, circular with all the hydrogen atoms directed in the same sense. The side lengths of the parallelogram are 2.832(3) and 2.808(3) Å and the O···O···O angles are 96.07(8) and 83.93(8)° around O9 and O10, respectively. Ab initio calculations as well as experimental evidence have shown that the optimal structure of the water tetramer is cyclic, quasi-planar, and with S 4 symmetry. The cyclic tetramer in 1 is effectively planar, but the four protons directed outward adopt the (up, up, down, down) sequence instead of (up, down, up, down), the point symmetry of the tetramer being C i . Although such tetramers are found to be less stable than the S 4 ones by ab initio calculations, another crystallographically characterized example has previously been reported, in which the crystal host, which likely contributes to stabilize this form of the tetramer, is [Cu(adipate)(4,4′-bipyridine)]. Each water tetramer in 1 is hydrogen bonded to six H4L molecules, with two of them being double donors and the four others simple acceptors. A three-dimensional framework is thus created, in which sheets of stacked [H4L] n chains parallel to the ab plane are separated by layers of water molecules.

Results and Discussion

H4L Dihydrate

H4L⋅2H2O (1) was obtained during an attempt at crystallizing the uranyl complex with deprotonated H4L (which could be done under slightly different conditions and will be reported elsewhere); a view of the structure is given in Figure . In the solid state, the H4L molecule is devoid of any symmetry element and it displays the expected geometry, with the all-cis configuration and all carboxylic groups in equatorial position. The four -COOH groups make dihedral angles of 59.04(18), 60.25(17), 61.0(2), and 43.4(3)° with the basal plane defined by the four atoms of the cyclohexane ring bearing the four carboxylic substituents (rms deviation 0.003 Å). Such tilting of proximal acid groups likely minimizes steric hindrance, as observed in all-trans 1,2,3,4,5,6-cyclohexanehexacarboxylate, with all the carboxylate groups in equatorial positions. Two proximal carboxylic groups are involved in hydrogen bonds with their counterparts in two different molecules (Table ), which results in the formation of zigzag chains directed along the b axis. The other two carboxylic groups are hydrogen bonded to the two water molecules, these being in their turn hydrogen bond donors toward each other or their image by symmetry and toward two unprotonated oxygen atoms from two different H4L molecules. Centrosymmetric, tetrameric water clusters are formed, in which the hydrogen bonding is homodromic, that is, circular with all the hydrogen atoms directed in the same sense. The side lengths of the parallelogram are 2.832(3) and 2.808(3) Å and the O⋅⋅⋅O⋅⋅⋅O angles are 96.07(8) and 83.93(8)° around O9 and O10, respectively. Ab initio calculations as well as experimental evidence have shown that the optimal structure of the water tetramer is cyclic, quasi-planar, and with S 4 symmetry. The cyclic tetramer in 1 is effectively planar, but the four protons directed outward adopt the (up, up, down, down) sequence instead of (up, down, up, down), the point symmetry of the tetramer being C  i . Although such tetramers are found to be less stable than the S 4 ones by ab initio calculations, another crystallographically characterized example has previously been reported, in which the crystal host, which likely contributes to stabilize this form of the tetramer, is [Cu(adipate)(4,4'-bipyridine)]. Each water tetramer in 1 is hydrogen bonded to six H4L molecules, with two of them being double donors and the four others simple acceptors. A three-dimensional framework is thus created, in which sheets of stacked [H4L] n  chains parallel to the ab plane are separated by layers of water molecules.

Depending on the stoichiometry of the reactants, two lithium complexes could be isolated. With a metal hydroxide/H4L ratio of 2:1, the complex [Li2(H2L)(H2O)2]·2H2O (2) was obtained (Figure ). The asymmetric unit contains one metal ion, half a H2L2− molecule with the group of four atoms containing the ethylene bridge being located on the mirror plane (x, 1/4, z), one coordinated and one free water molecules. The Li+ ion is bound to three oxygen atoms from three different molecules, with an average Li−O bond length of 1.918(7) Å which matches the average value of 1.93(4) Å calculated from the CSD for 4-coordinated lithium ions. The water molecule completes the coordination sphere, with an unremarkable bond length of 1.974(3) Å [average from the CSD 1.94(4) Å]. The coordination polyhedron is a quite regular tetrahedron, with O−Li−O angles in the range 102.52(15)−119.50(17)°. The H2L2− molecule connects six cations (Scheme ), the two equivalent carboxylate groups being bidentate and bridging two cations in syn/anti fashion, and the two carboxylic groups monodentate through their carbonyl oxygen atoms. The two independent carboxylic/ate groups make dihedral angles of 56.62(13)° (O1, O2) and 56.20(12)° (O3, O4) with the basal plane of the cyclohexane ring, and of 59.83(19)° with one another. The polymeric structure is three-dimensional, with an alternation of sheets of H2L2− with sheets of Li+ ions parallel to the ac plane. The total point symbol for the binodal net is (42, 6)2(44, 62, 89), which corresponds to the topological type flu-3,6-Pnma in the database binodal.ttd. One of the other two examples of this topology is also a lithium complex, with a glycoluril carboxylate derivative. The arrangement is quite compact, with a Kitaigorodski packing index of 0.79, or 0.70 with the solvent molecules excluded (estimation with PLATON).

elements.content: With a metal hydroxide/H4L ratio of 4:1, the complex [Li4(L)(H2O)3.5]·1.5H2O (3) was reproducibly obtained instead and its structure is represented in Figure . The asymmetric unit comprises eight Li+ ions, two tetracarboxylate molecules, seven coordinated and three free water molecules. The atoms Li2−Li6 and Li8 are four-coordinate, being bound either to three different monodentate L4− and one water molecules (Li2, Li5, Li8), or to one bidentate (through two monodentate carboxylate groups) and two monodentate L4− molecules (Li3, Li4, Li6). Atom Li1 is bound to two monodentate L4− and two water molecules, but it is also involved in a quite short contact with one carbon atom of the ethylene bridge of one ligand, ca. 2.56 Å, a value comparable to those reported in the CSD for lithium π-bonding to double bond systems. Atom Li7 is chelated by one carboxylate group, in a very asymmetric fashion since the two bond lengths differ by ca. 0.6 Å, and is also bound to three water molecules. The average Li−O(carboxylate) and Li−O(water) for the four-coordinate ions are 1.95(5) and 2.03(7) Å, respectively; these values are larger than in 2 since several donor atoms are bridging. The coordination polyhedra of these cations are distorted tetrahedral, with O−Li−O angles in the range 92.5(3)−124.5(3)°. The coordination polyhedron around the five-coordinated Li1 is a distorted square pyramid with O9 in axial position, while that around Li7 is irregular, being closer to a distorted tetrahedron with an extra, longer bond to O7. The cations are bound to either one (Li7), two (Li1), or three (all others) L4− molecules, while the two ligands are bound through all their oxygen atoms and connect 11 (O1−O8) or 10 (O9−O16) cations (Scheme ). The resulting three-dimensional framework is extremely intricate and the 10-nodal net has the total point symbol (414, 618, 813)(43)2(45, 6)(4), for which no other example exists in the databases included in the TOPOS package. The packing index amounts to 0.83 (0.77 with solvent molecules excluded). Narrow channels running down the a axis are apparent, but they are obstructed by the pendent Li7(H2O)3 groups. It is noteworthy that channels are present in the three-dimensional framework formed by lithium succinate, which was reported long ago.

elements.content: The sodium ion complex [Na2(H2L)(H2O)3]·H2O (4) presents the same metal/ligand stoichiometry as 2, but the asymmetric unit comprises two independent cations and one H2L2− molecule. Atom Na1 is bound to three oxygen atoms from carboxylic/ate groups pertaining to three different molecules, among which two are bridging, and to three water molecules, one of them bridging; Na2 is bound to four atoms from three H2L2− molecules and to the bridging water molecule, and it is also involved in a weak interaction with the ethylene carbon atom C12 (Figure ). Both coordination polyhedra are distorted octahedral and the cations are arranged in triply bridged pairs [Na···Na distance 3.1881(17) Å]. The average Na−O(H2L) bond lengths for monodentate and bridging atoms are identical, at 2.39(3) and 2.42(13) Å, respectively, in agreement with the corresponding mean values from the CSD, 2.40(12) and 2.42(12) Å. The average Na−O(water) bond lengths are 2.31(10) and 2.38(9) Å for terminal and bridging atoms, respectively, somewhat smaller than their counterparts from the CSD [2.40(9) and 2.42(8) Å]. The dihedral angles between the carboxylic/ate groups and the cyclohexane basal plane are similar to those in 2, with values in the range of 48.0(2)−69.1(2)° and the angles between proximal groups are 43.0(2) and 48.8(4)°. In contrast with complex 2, the two carboxylic groups are proximal and an intramolecular hydrogen bond is formed between them. The H2L2− molecule connects six cations and three oxygen atoms are left uncoordinated (Scheme ). The polymeric assembly is two-dimensional and parallel to the ab plane, with thick layers spanning the complete unit cell in the c axis direction. The triply bridged cation pairs are connected to one another so as to form tubular subunits directed along the a axis, in which each ligand is bound to three successive pairs (Figure ). However, since the bridging cations in these subunits are bound on the side of the H2L2− molecule which comprises the ethylene bridge, the latter points toward the tubule center, thus preventing a cavity to be formed. The total point symbol for the 4-nodal net is (43, 62, 8)(44, 68, 83)(45, 6)(4) (for Na1, H2L, Na2 and O9, respectively), for which no other example is reported in the databases included in the TOPOS package. The packing index is 0.78 (0.74 with solvent molecules excluded) and no significant free space is present.

elements.content: The potassium ion complex [K2(H2L)(H2O)2]·H2O (5) presents some similarities with 4, in particular, the stoichiometry and the arrangement of cations in triply bridged pairs. Each metal atom is bound to five carboxylic/ate oxygen atoms (four of them bridging, one chelating group for K1) and two bridging water molecules, K1 being also involved in an interaction with the ethylene carbon atom C12 (Figure ). The overall average K−O(H2L) and K−O(water) bond lengths, 2.83(10) and 2.87(11) Å, respectively, match the mean values from the CSD, 2.81(15) and 2.82(12) Å. Both coordination polyhedra are extremely distorted, with no obvious regular geometry discernible. K1 is bound to three and K2 to four different H2L2− molecules, while the ligand connects seven cations, one of them chelated by the carboxylate group containing O5 and O6 and two others chelated by two proximal carboxylic/ate groups (Scheme ). The dihedral angles between the carboxylic/ate groups and the cyclohexane basal plane cover a wider range than in 4, with values in the range of 47.55(10)−87.83(13)° and the angles between proximal groups are 46.9(2) and 65.4(2)°. The K1···K2 distance in the triply bridged pairs is 3.9613(6) Å; these pairs are bound to one another along the a axis by double bridges corresponding to a larger K···K distance of 4.4163(7) Å. Two rows of alternate doubly and triply bridged cation pairs are connected by H2L2− molecules so as to form tubular subunits directed along the a axis, in which each ligand is bound to four pairs. These subunits are further arranged into two-dimensional larger subunits parallel to the ac plane, which are reminiscent of those found in 4. The bridging water molecules (O10) finally ensure the assembling of these sheets into a three-dimensional framework (Figure ). The total point symbol for the 5-nodal net is (413, 68)(45, 6, 84)(47, 63, 85)(4)(8) (for H2L, K1, K2, O9, and O10, respectively; no other example reported in the databases included in the TOPOS package). The packing index is 0.82 (0.79 with solvent molecules excluded) and no significant free space is present.

elements.content: The two complexes [Rb(H3L)(H2O)] (6) and [Cs(H3L)(H2O)] (7) might be considered to be isomorphous, but, due to the different radii of the cations, the connectivity varies, which results in different dimensionalities for the assemblies (Figures and ). The asymmetric unit in both complexes comprises one cation, one singly deprotonated H3L− molecule, and one terminal water ligand. The H3L− molecule possesses a pseudobinary axis bisecting the ethylene bridge, and the dihedral angles between the carboxylic/ate groups and the mean plane of the cyclohexane ring are nearly identical for the two halves of the molecule, one group being more tilted than the other (ca. 68−71 and 53−54°, respectively), while the angles between proximal groups are ca. 45 and 47° in 6 and 7, respectively. The rubidium atom in 6 is bound to two ligands which are chelating through proximal carboxylic/ate groups, to two monodentate groups pertaining to two more molecules and to the water molecule, with an average Rb−O(H3L) bond length of 3.04(18) Å, to be compared to the mean value of 2.98(15) Å from the CSD; the Rb−O(water) of 3.0330(14) Å is also in agreement with the mean value from the CSD, 3.00(11) Å. The seven-coordinate environment is distorted pentagonal bipyramidal, with atoms O1, O3, O5′′, O7′′, and O7′′′ defining the basal plane (rms deviation 0.20 Å) and O2′ and O9 as apexes [O2′−Rb−O9 149.89(4)°]. The cesium atom in 7 is bound to the same atoms as the rubidium ion in 6, with an extra, longer bond to the atom O4 from another molecule, with an average Cs−O(H3L) and a Cs−O(water) bond lengths of 3.2(2) Å and 3.1520(16) Å [3.2(2) and 3.28(17) Å, respectively, from the CSD]. The eight-coordinate environment displays a very irregular geometry. Weak interactions of the metal with both ethylene bridge atoms are indicated by Rb···C and Cs···C distances of ca. 4−4.1 and 4.2−4.3 Å, respectively. The cations are thus bound to either four (6) or five (7) H3L− molecules, while, conversely, the latter is bound to four or five cations (Scheme ). The resulting assembly in 6 is two-dimensional, with thick layers parallel to (1 0 0) and spanning one unit cell length along the a axis. This assembly is uninodal, since both cations and anions possess the same point symbol, (44, 62), which corresponds to a tetragonal planar net (sql/Shubnikov in topos&RCSR.ttd). The extra bond present around cesium in 7 results in the extension of this arrangement into a three-dimensional, uninodal framework with the total point symbol (46, 64), corresponding to the quite common topological type bnn hexagonal BN (topos&RCSR.ttd); both nodes are in distorted square pyramidal environments in the simplified network. As in complexes 4 and 5, tubular subunits running along the a axis can be discerned in 7, but they are more closely fused with one another than in the previous cases. The packing indexes amount to 0.80 and 0.82 in 6 and 7, respectively, with no free space present.

elements.content: The complex [Ba2(L)(H2O)5]·0.5H2O (8) is, after the Sr2+ complex [Sr2(L)(H2O)4] previously reported, the second example of an alkaline-earth complex with this ligand and its structure is represented in Figure . The asymmetric unit comprises two independent barium atoms and one fully deprotonated ligand. The carboxylate groups form dihedral angles of 52−78° with the mean plane and 51 and 47° between proximal groups. The atom Ba1 is bound to seven atoms from carboxylate groups (two of them chelating and very asymmetric) pertaining to four L4− molecules, and to two water molecules, with a very irregular nine-coordinate environment geometry. Ba2 is bound to five oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups (one chelating) from three molecules and to four water molecules, the environment geometry being capped square antiprismatic, with a dihedral angle of 12.08(11)° between the two square faces (O1, O5∧, O8′′′, O9#) and (O6∧, O11, O12, O13) and with O3 in capping position. The average Ba−O(L) bond lengths are 2.92(17) and 2.75(5) Å for chelating and monodentate carboxylate groups, respectively, and the average Ba−O(water) bond length is 2.86(5) Å [2.87(10), 2.75(8), and 2.82(8) Å, respectively, from the CSD]. Each L4− molecule is bound to seven cations, three being chelated by single carboxylate groups, two chelated through two different groups and the others bound in monodentate fashion (Scheme ). In contrast, the cation in the strontium complex is bound to three different L4− molecules (one monodentate, one chelating, and one both chelating and monodentate) and to three water molecules (two bridging); each L4− molecule is also bound to seven cations. The large coordination number of the cation and denticity of the ligand result in the formation of a three-dimensional framework of unprecedented topology in compound 8, with the total point symbol (44, 62)(45, 64, 8)(49, 69, 83)(4) (for the four nodes Ba2, Ba1, L, and O9, respectively). Very narrow channels running along the [0 1 1] direction, with a section of approximate dimensions 6.3 × 2 Å, contain the solvent water molecules, which are hydrogen bonded to one of the water ligands. The packing index of 0.82 (0.80 with solvent molecules excluded) is however indicative of a compact framework.
elements.clean_text:
Ba2+ Complex

The complex [Ba2(L)(H2O)5]⋅0.5H2O (8) is, after the Sr2+ complex [Sr2(L)(H2O)4] previously reported, the second example of an alkaline-earth complex with this ligand and its structure is represented in Figure . The asymmetric unit comprises two independent barium atoms and one fully deprotonated ligand. The carboxylate groups form dihedral angles of 52-78° with the mean plane and 51 and 47° between proximal groups. The atom Ba1 is bound to seven atoms from carboxylate groups (two of them chelating and very asymmetric) pertaining to four L4- molecules, and to two water molecules, with a very irregular nine-coordinate environment geometry. Ba2 is bound to five oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups (one chelating) from three molecules and to four water molecules, the environment geometry being capped square antiprismatic, with a dihedral angle of 12.08(11)° between the two square faces (O1, O5∧, O8''', O9#) and (O6∧, O11, O12, O13) and with O3 in capping position. The average Ba-O(L) bond lengths are 2.92(17) and 2.75(5) Å for chelating and monodentate carboxylate groups, respectively, and the average Ba-O(water) bond length is 2.86(5) Å [2.87(10), 2.75(8), and 2.82(8) Å, respectively, from the CSD]. Each L4- molecule is bound to seven cations, three being chelated by single carboxylate groups, two chelated through two different groups and the others bound in monodentate fashion (Scheme ). In contrast, the cation in the strontium complex is bound to three different L4- molecules (one monodentate, one chelating, and one both chelating and monodentate) and to three water molecules (two bridging); each L4- molecule is also bound to seven cations. The large coordination number of the cation and denticity of the ligand result in the formation of a three-dimensional framework of unprecedented topology in compound 8, with the total point symbol (44, 62)(45, 64, 8)(49, 69, 83)(4) (for the four nodes Ba2, Ba1, L, and O9, respectively). Very narrow channels running along the [0 1 1] direction, with a section of approximate dimensions 6.3 × 2 Å, contain the solvent water molecules, which are hydrogen bonded to one of the water ligands. The packing index of 0.82 (0.80 with solvent molecules excluded) is however indicative of a compact framework.

elements.content: The six complexes 2−7 reported herein are the first alkali metal ion complexes with a cyclohexane polycarboxylate derivative and 8 is only the second such complex with an alkaline-earth ion. These compounds are also rare examples of the use of the all-exo isomer of bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid (H4L) as a ligand, although this molecule presents the interesting features of a rigid cyclohexane ring in the boat conformation and four divergent carboxylic groups in the equatorial positions, with the only rotations possible for these groups being about their linkage to the ring. It is a remarkable characteristic of the present complexes of H4−x L x− with the complete alkali metal ion series, as well as those with barium and strontium, that no two present identical bonding schemes (the rubidium and cesium complexes being closest to one another). When present, the carboxylic groups are monodentate or bridging bidentate (with either one or two oxygen atoms involved in the latter case), while the carboxylate groups span the whole range of possible bonding modes, being either chelating, mono-, bi-, tri-, or even tetradentate as in complex 3. The largest overall denticity of the ligand is obtained with lithium ions in complex 3, with as many as 11 cations bound to a single L4− molecule, whereas this number is in the range 4−7 for the other complexes, the lower values of 4 and 5 being obtained for the cations with the larger ionic radii, rubidium and cesium. This trend is at variance with that in the complexes formed by sodium, potassium, and cesium ions with pyrazinetetracarboxylic acid, in which the largest ligand denticity of 12 corresponds to cesium. Clearly, the outcome of the reaction of alkali metal ions with ligands displaying such large arrays of coordinating atoms is quite unpredictable. A common characteristic of the present complexes is to crystallize as compact three-dimensional (or two-dimensional with sodium and rubidium) assemblies, with no significant free spaces, apart from those containing the limited number of water solvent molecules, when present. An interesting feature is the presence of slightly different, narrow tubular subunits in the sodium and potassium complexes. Further work aiming at extending the use of this ligand to other cations is presently in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The six complexes 2-7 reported herein are the first alkali metal ion complexes with a cyclohexane polycarboxylate derivative and 8 is only the second such complex with an alkaline-earth ion. These compounds are also rare examples of the use of the all-exo isomer of bicyclo[2.2.2]oct-7-ene-2,3,5,6-tetracarboxylic acid (H4L) as a ligand, although this molecule presents the interesting features of a rigid cyclohexane ring in the boat conformation and four divergent carboxylic groups in the equatorial positions, with the only rotations possible for these groups being about their linkage to the ring. It is a remarkable characteristic of the present complexes of H4-x L x- with the complete alkali metal ion series, as well as those with barium and strontium, that no two present identical bonding schemes (the rubidium and cesium complexes being closest to one another). When present, the carboxylic groups are monodentate or bridging bidentate (with either one or two oxygen atoms involved in the latter case), while the carboxylate groups span the whole range of possible bonding modes, being either chelating, mono-, bi-, tri-, or even tetradentate as in complex 3. The largest overall denticity of the ligand is obtained with lithium ions in complex 3, with as many as 11 cations bound to a single L4- molecule, whereas this number is in the range 4-7 for the other complexes, the lower values of 4 and 5 being obtained for the cations with the larger ionic radii, rubidium and cesium. This trend is at variance with that in the complexes formed by sodium, potassium, and cesium ions with pyrazinetetracarboxylic acid, in which the largest ligand denticity of 12 corresponds to cesium. Clearly, the outcome of the reaction of alkali metal ions with ligands displaying such large arrays of coordinating atoms is quite unpredictable. A common characteristic of the present complexes is to crystallize as compact three-dimensional (or two-dimensional with sodium and rubidium) assemblies, with no significant free spaces, apart from those containing the limited number of water solvent molecules, when present. An interesting feature is the presence of slightly different, narrow tubular subunits in the sodium and potassium complexes. Further work aiming at extending the use of this ligand to other cations is presently in progress.

Lda (50 mg, 0.20 mmol), LiOH·H2O (17 mg, 0.41 mmol), and demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure until complete dissolution (about 15 mn). The solution was then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature and colorless crystals of complex 2 appeared within two weeks (36 mg, 49% yield). Anal. Calcd. for C12H18Li2O12: C, 39.15; H, 4.93. Found: C, 39.06; H, 4.79%.

[Li<sub>4</sub>(L)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3.5</sub>]·1.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>)

Lda (25 mg, 0.10 mmol), LiOH·H2O (17 mg, 0.41 mmol), and demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure until complete dissolution (about 15 mn). The solution was then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature and colorless crystals of complex 3 appeared within six weeks (24 mg, 60% yield). Anal. Calcd. for C12H18Li4O13: C, 36.21; H, 4.56. Found: C, 35.76; H, 4.25%.

[Na<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>L)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

Lda (50 mg, 0.20 mmol), NaOH (24 mg, 0.60 mmol), and demineralized water (2.4 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure until complete dissolution (about 15 mn). The solution was then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature, and colorless crystals of complex 4 appeared within three days (28 mg, 35% yield based on the acid). Anal. Calcd. for C12H18Na2O12: C, 36.01; H, 4.53. Found: C, 35.71; H, 4.56%.

[K<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>L)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

Lda (50 mg, 0.20 mmol), KOH (34 mg, 0.61 mmol), and demineralized water (2.5 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure until complete dissolution (about 15 mn). The solution was then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature, and colorless crystals of complex 5 appeared in low yield within six weeks.

[Rb(H<sub>3</sub>L)(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (<bold>6</bold>)

Lda (50 mg, 0.20 mmol), RbOH (61 mg, 0.60 mmol), and demineralized water (1.3 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure until complete dissolution (about 15 mn). The solution was then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature, and colorless crystals of complex 6 appeared in low yield within two weeks.

[Cs(H<sub>3</sub>L)(H<sub>2</sub>O)] (<bold>7</bold>)

Lda (25 mg, 0.10 mmol), CsOH·H2O (34 mg, 0.20 mmol), and demineralized water (1.5 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure until complete dissolution (about 15 mn). The solution was then left to slowly evaporate at room temperature, and colorless crystals of complex 7 appeared within one week (7 mg, 16% yield based on the acid). Anal. Calcd. for C12H13CsO9: C, 33.20; H, 3.02. Found: C, 33.20; H, 2.90%.

[Ba<sub>2</sub>(L)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>5</sub>]·0.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>8</bold>)

Lda (25 mg, 0.10 mmol), BaCO3 (79 mg, 0.40 mmol), and demineralized water (2 mL) were placed in a 15 mL tightly closed glass vessel and heated at 180 °C under autogenous pressure, yielding colorless crystals of complex 8, in low yield and mixed with a powder which was not further characterized, within 24 h.
